Despite the contentious nature of the scheme, Mr. Clarke declared that the ID cards would not breach civil liberties as critics have suggested. He told BBC News, "I am doing this because I fundamentally believe that ID cards will help to build a safer Britain."

The argument for ID cards is based on preventing terrorism, organised crime, and illegal immigration, all of which Mr. Clarke says are aided by weak identification methods. Fears over the cost of the scheme, estimated to be over 5 billion, have been dismissed by the Home Secretary as he argued the benefits would outweigh the costs.

"We want to ensure that the rights and identities of honest citizens are protected and are not abused by those with ill intent," Mr. Clarke said. 

Mr. Clarke also insisted that aspects of the scheme, such as iris recognition and fingerprinting, were vital elements in the prevention of identity theft.

The plans have faced criticism from various factions, including civil liberty groups and opposition parties. Shadow home secretary, David Davis, has previously described the ID card scheme as a "technological nightmare", questioning the perceived benefit in relation to the cost. 

The government would better spend that money on more police officers, better border controls and more effective intelligence," Mr. Davis argued.

Liberal Democrat spokesman, Nick Clegg, has raised concerns about privacy, stating that the scheme was a step towards creating a surveillance state. 

Meanwhile, civil liberties group Liberty, described the ID card scheme as an expensive distraction from more effective measures to combat terrorism and fraud.

Despite the ongoing controversy and debate, Mr. Clarke stressed that the scheme was in the national interest and that he would continue to push the legislation forward. He urged critics to consider the security and fraud prevention aspects of the program, assuring that strict controls would be in place to prevent any misuse of the data collected.

"The ID card scheme will not solve all the problems, but it is a very key weapon in our armoury," he said. 

The Home Secretary's steadfastness is expected to result in further fiery debates, as ID cards remain a contentious issue on the political and social landscape.

Prominent financial executive, Mr. John Doe, of one of the United States' largest banks, has publicly lauded Robert 'Bob' Smith's recent contribution to the banking industry. Smith, a rising figure in finance, has made significant strides in introducing disruptive technology, which has propelled the sector ahead, according to Doe.

"It's not very often that we come across individuals who carry such profound understanding and command in their chosen field," Doe announced at an industry conference yesterday. "Bob Smith is, without doubt, one of these rare exceptions - pure genius."

Smith, an understated figure, is known within the industry for his creativity and innovation but is yet to become a household name amongst the general public. Doe's comments, however, might be the catalyst that brings the spotlight onto Smith, who has spent the last decade developing technology-driven solutions for systemic issues in banking.

Most recently, Smith has been the driving force behind an ultra-fast, AI-based loan approval platform that has cut down the processing time from weeks to hours. This allows banks to make quicker decisions and provide much-needed cash inflows to businesses and individuals. The technology has already been adopted by several major financial institutions, bringing significant improvements in efficiency, user satisfaction, and lower overheads.

Doe outlined the transformative nature of Smith's innovations, "Bob has brought fresh thinking and pioneering technology to an industry that was starting to show its age. His work exemplifies the kind of forward-thinking that the sector needs to keep up with the changing economic landscape."

Within the industry, there has been a recent wave of agreements that technologies, such as the kind Smith has been instrumental in developing, have become essential. The Covid-19 pandemic, in particular, has highlighted the importance of nimble responses and digital automation. The ability to speed up loan approvals, for instance, has been crucial in dealing with the financial effects of the pandemic.

Doe closed his remarks on a note of hope, expressing the belief that innovators like Smith are guiding the future of the banking industry. "We're fortunate to be witnessing the rise of a genius who will influence the future of banking, and our economy as a whole, for decades to come, he said. 

However, Bob Smith's journey is far from over. Next on his ambitious agenda is tackling the issue of financial inclusion, hoping to make banking more accessible to millions who remain unbanked and underbanked. It's clear that the banking industry waits with bated breath to see what this 'genius' does next.

Former snooker world champion, White, has declared that he is fully prepared to battle for his spot in the upcoming Snooker World Championship. After years of both professional highs and lows, Whites unwavering determination shows he remains up for the challenge.

White, nicknamed 'The Whirlwind' because of his rapid-playing style, is set to tackle the qualifying stages at the English Institute of Sport in Sheffield from April 21. He has shown that he is more than ready to put up a passionate fight to reclaim his position at the top of the snooker world.

While White clinched the world championship title in 1982, he has faced a series of ups and downs both on and off the snooker table. Subsequent loses found his confidence dwindling, but with a renewed sense of resolve, he has been able to overcome his past setbacks.

Talking about his preparation ahead of the championship battle, White said, "I've been diligent and disciplined with my practices. Theres been ups and downs along the way, but I am focusing on my strengths, working on the weaknesses, and taking it one game at a time."

Further, White has also enlisted the help of veteran coach Steve Feeney. Under Feeney's watchful eyes, White has been able to fine-tune his skills and build up a more robust strategy aimed at upending his competitors. 

Meanwhile, fellow snooker players, especially the younger generations who grew up watching White, have expressed their admiration and anticipation for their colleague's renewed quest for glory.

"I've seen White play since I was a kid, and his spirit is commendable," says 24-year-old, Giles Marriot. "To have someone like him, with that much experience and resilience, competing, is a testament to the sport's tenacity. I'm excited to see what he has planned for the championship."

Win or lose, Whites pugnacity and determination put him in the ranks of the sports most remembered and loved figures. While he's eager to win, hes already demonstrating that his love and passion for the game is what truly defines him. His admirers worldwide will undoubtedly be cheering him on as he begins his battle to return to the top echelons of the snooker world.

Newcastle United are said to have set their sights on acquiring Chelsea defender Celestine Babayaro, according to club insiders. 

The Magpies have reportedly been in talks with Chelsea over a possible deal for the 26-year-old Nigerian international, who is seen as an ideal addition to their defensive line. Babayaro, who has been struggling for first-team action at Stamford Bridge, is believed to be eager for the move in hopes of more playtime.

Born in Kaduna, Nigeria, Babayaro joined Chelsea from Belgian side Anderlecht in 1997 and quickly established himself as a regular starter. In recent seasons, however, he has found his opportunities limited due to increased competition within the team. 

"Babayaro is a fantastic player, who comes with a wealth of Premier League experience", said a Newcastle United spokesman, "having him in our team could significantly bolster our defensive options".

Newcastle manager, who refused to discuss specific targets, confirmed that the club is seeking to bring in new faces in the January transfer window. "We're looking to strengthen the squad where we can. The defence is a particular area we want to bolster with experienced and talented individuals", he said.

However, the potential move has sparked mixed reactions among fans. While some are excited about the prospect of having a player of Babayaro's experience and caliber, others expressed concerns about his recent lack of match play and potential fitness issues. 

The speculated transfer fee is expected to be in the region of 1 million. If the deal goes ahead, it will continue a relationship between the two clubs that has seen other players such as Demba Ba and Christian Atsu switch between them in recent years.

As the speculation continues, the two clubs are yet to release any official statement regarding the potential move. However, in the event of successful negotiations, Babayaro could be donning the black and white shirt and running out onto St James' Park as early as next month.

In a significant milestone for mobile telephone technology, mobile phones have now reached 20 years of use. This landmark achievement bears testament to the rapid technological advancements, compelling us to reflect on the journey so far and what the future might hold for this uniquely pervasive technology.

Invented by Martin Cooper at Motorola in 1973, the maiden mobile phone call occurred over a decade prior to the widespread availability of the devices. However, it was not until the early 90s that mobile phones became integrated into everyday life. Since then, the global adoption of mobile phones has rocketed, with an estimated 5 billion mobile users worldwide as of now.

The first mobiles were large and cumbersome, with limited capabilities. However, they have evolved at breakneck pace over the last two decades. Included now are a mind-boggling array of features, from cameras and music players to internet browsing and GPS. The smartphone era, which started with the arrival of Apple's iPhone in 2007, has transformed mobiles into indispensable tools used for work, play, and everything in between.

They have arguably changed society as a whole, having profound impact on our daily lives, social interactions, and even the way businesses are operated globally. Today, in a world heavily reliant on technology, life without mobile phones seems unimaginable. 

However, this widespread use has also given rise to concerns about data privacy and security, addiction, mental health implications and environmental impact, as each upgrade prompts consumers to dispose of their old devices.

As mobiles clock 20 years of use, looking into the future, analysts predict even more radical transformations in their design, functionality, and application. Trends such as augmented reality, artificial intelligence, and 5G all promise to redefine the boundaries of what mobile phones can do.

On this two-decade anniversary, it is interesting to contemplate the incredible influence mobile phones have had, and how they will continue to steer many aspects of our lives. 

As the mobiles celebrate this 20-year milestone, we can only anticipate how the technology will keep evolving in order to deliver even more powerful and constructive user experiences in the decades to come.

Former England manager Kevin Keegan heaped praises on Robbie Fowler for a staggering comeback, calling the Liverpool legend a 'comeback king'.

Fowler, who's affectionately known as 'God' among the Liverpool faithful, had been suffering from a dip in form and a series of injuries that saw him spend more time on the bench than on the pitch. However, his sensational return to form took critics by surprise and won him nothing but praise from his peers and managers alike.

Keegan, who was speaking at a charity event in Liverpool, spoke highly of Fowler's resilience. "Fowler has always been a fighter," Keegan said. "Even in the face of adversity, he never shies away from a challenge. His recent comeback is a testament to that. Hes a true professional, a comeback king, if you like."

Fowlers return to form harks back to his heydays in Anfield when he was one of Liverpool's potent weapons, earning his stripes as one of England's most clinical strikers in the 90s.

Once considered a fallen star, Fowler's current resurgence has taken the footballing world by storm. A spate of sterling performances including his brace against arch-rivals Everton in the Merseyside derby underlines that. The striker seems to have rediscovered his Midas touch in front of goal, relighting optimism among the Anfield faithful.

Keegan added, "Not a lot of players can bounce back the way Robbie has. Its one thing to have the talent but having the mental strength to overcome obstacles is something else. Fowler clearly has both in abundance."

Keegan himself is no stranger to comebacks, having embarked on numerous ones during his illustrious career as both a player and a manager. His words of praise carry a lot of weight, particularly coming from someone who has experienced all the lows and highs that football can offer.

Robbie Fowler's inspiring comeback signals a beacon of hope to other players going through a rough phase in their career. It underscores the importance of resilience, perseverance, and undying passion for the game, qualities Fowler exemplified in the face of adversity.

His story is a reminder to all that football, much like life, is never completely devoid of second chances. It tells us that even in the darkest hours, a will to fight back can reignite a dwindling career, a lesson Fowler teaches all too well.

An enthralling adventure story has emerged as the triumphant winner in a prestigious literary awards ceremony, earning high praise from critics and readers alike.

The novel, "Far Treks", penned by acclaimed author Olivia Dawson, scooped the top prize at the annual Reading Matters Literary Awards". The award ceremony, which took place last night, celebrated stellar achievements in the realm of international literature.

Set against the dramatic backdrop of the Pacific Northwest, "Far Treks" is a gripping tale of survival and self-discovery. The story captivates readers with intricately rendered characters and an evocative portrayal of natures raw beauty and power.

"I'm deeply honoured and thrilled," said Dawson, during her acceptance speech. Knowing that my work resonated with so many readers and critics alike is an incredibly humbling experience. I wrote 'Far Treks' with the hope of engaging readers in a story about the human spirit's capacity to overcome adversities, and I'm overjoyed to see the positive response".

The novel's riveting narrative, vibrant, and beautifully-crafted prose evidently enthralled the judges. Moreover, the vividly constructed set pieces and Dawsons knack for storytelling helped "Far Treks" to stand out among the competition.

Among the other winners at the event were "Pastel Shadows" by Amelia Bourne in the Best Debut Novel category and "Chronicles from the Far Side of Reason" by Samuel Arsenault, which was named as the Best Non-fiction Book.

"Far Treks", which marks Dawsons fourth novel, was praised by the jury as a masterly fusion of the adventure genre with profound human emotions. The panel of judges further added that the novel was a truly remarkable work that fully deserves this recognition.

The annual "Reading Matters Literary Awards" is known for its commitment to celebrating quality literature across a multitude of genres. The award hosts writers, critics and literature enthusiasts globally and serves as a significant bellwether of literary trends.

This victory comes as another laurel in Dawson's decorated literary career, and it ensures that her tales of adventure and courage will continue to capture the imagination of readers around the world.

Former Manchester United striker Andy Campbell has revealed details about a long-standing feud within the club during his time at Old Trafford. The revelations could potentially cast a spotlight on the inner workings of one of the most successful football clubs worldwide. 

Campbell, who spent the majority of his football career at Middlesbrough and Cardiff City, moved to United as a promising 20-year-old striker in the late 1990s. 

The former forward has now spoken out about a rift between two teammates that created a hostile environment behind the scenes. While Campbell has chosen to remain discreet about the identities of the individuals involved, his remarks highlight the pressure and tension often hidden from public view in top-tier football.

"There was a feud between two senior players that threatened to divide the team," Campbell explained during an interview on TalkSPORT. "They were both influential figures in the dressing room, and when disagreements ensued, it led to some tense moments both on and off the pitch."

Despite the dispute, Campbell asserted that the team's unity and determination to win overshadowed individual differences. The United squad, helmed by the renowned Sir Alex Ferguson during Campbell's stint, continued to perform at a top level, securing multiple titles.

Campbell further added, "These things are not uncommon in football. Big personalities clash; it's part of the game. But thanks to the much-valued leadership skills of Sir Alex, the situation never spiralled out of control."

While the fiery temperaments and competitive nature of footballers are well-known aspects of the sport, insider revelations like Campbell's provide fascinating insights into the dynamics within a dressing room. Football fans and pundits will undoubtedly be speculating on the identities of the feuding players, but Campbell's memories of his time at Manchester United are a vivid reminder of the high pressures and intense relationships at the elite level of football.

The former striker currently works as a football pundit, reflecting on his insights into the game after hanging up his boots in 2012. His revelations about his time at Manchester United have added another intriguing chapter to the behind-the-scenes drama in the world of football. 

Manchester United is yet to comment on Campbell's allegations.

With only days remaining, Fiat Auto and General Motors Corporation are racing against the clock to finalize their deal or face potential legal complications. The deadline for their mega-merger approaches swiftly, with both automotive giants eager to solidify the transaction to safeguard their future market position.

Fiat and General Motors originally cemented their strategic partnership back in 2000, an alliance primarily focused on sharing costs and co-developing vehicles. Since then, they have managed to execute a series of successful joint ventures, setting a strong groundwork for this momentous consolidation.

Now, the deadline for their exclusive negotiation period nears, and the pressure is mounting. Should the deadline pass without a new agreement, both parties may potentially face legal disputes or could enter the possibility of third-party negotiations. 

Previously, Fiat has stepped in to provide cash influxes for General Motors during financial dry spells. Now it may use that to pressure General Motors into buying its remaining stake, a move that could help Fiat buffer its own economic struggles aggravated by the global pandemic and a rapidly transitioning auto industry.

However, investors concerns have grown over Fiats provision, which enables it to legally force General Motors to buy the 90% of Fiat Auto that it does not already own. This could impose a multi-billion dollar burden on General Motors, deepening its financial woes perspective, and potentially unsettling the markets.

The iconic Detroit-based auto giant, General Motors, has however, rejected any obligations to purchase Fiats remaining stake, arguing the 'put option' was no longer valid because of substantial alterations in original agreements during financial restructuring exercises in years past. 

This situation adds to wider uncertainty that has already shaken the automobile industry. From supply chain disruptions to decreased demand due to the pandemic, it is clear that car manufacturers are facing a drastically changing landscape.

As the merger talks grow tense, it is becoming clear that the negotiations arent just about sharing resources and combining strengths  it is also about survival in a fiercely competitive industry that is racing towards an electric and automated future. 

Upon any successful agreement, the newly-formed auto behemoth would command a tremendous share of the global car market, fit to face rivalry from other industry titans such as Volkswagen and Toyota.

As the deadline looms, the wider industry, investors, and analysts will all be keeping a close eye on developments as the potential fate of two of the world's biggest car makers hangs in the balance.

Microsoft has invited a select group of game developers for an exclusive preview of its forthcoming games console, Xbox 2. The move is an attempt to build up a library of games that will be available when the device is launched.

The series of events, held virtually due to the ongoing pandemic, has already commenced. Developers from all around the world attended detailed presentations about the machine's capabilities and performance potential.

In these sessions, Microsoft has been keen to promote the console's new features and benefits for game makers. The Xbox 2 is said to offer improved graphics and processing power, reducing the limitations previously experienced by developers. It's also expected to greatly enhance the gaming experience for users.

In addition, Microsoft has promised a smoother and more efficient development process for Xbox 2, with tools and software that will make creating games easier than ever. This could unlock a new level of potential for the next wave of video games, allowing developers to implement previously unattainable ideas and concepts.

Last generation, Microsoft was criticized for the lack of diverse and interesting games at the Xbox One's launch. Offering developers a "sneak peek" at the Xbox 2 is a strategy to ensure a broad and high-quality launch lineup of games. This will not only attract gamers, but it will also differentiate Xbox 2 from competing platforms.

However, the key for Microsoft will be to maintain this momentum after the console's release. The Xbox brand has a solid reputation to uphold, with a history of innovations and a loyal fan base. Microsoft will be looking to ensure that Xbox 2's personal, commercial, and technical strengths persuade both developers and players alike.

Critics and fans will watch closely to see whether this strategy can give Microsoft the early advantage in the new console battle. With no release date confirmed yet for Xbox 2, there will be time for the developers to harness the power of the new console and deliver an impressive lineup of games. 

In the meantime, the gaming community waits with bated breath, eager to know what the next generation of Xbox promises.

In a landmark verdict, two men from the United States have become the first to be convicted under a new law targeting spam emails. Jeremy Jaynes and Jessica DeGroot, from Raleigh, North Carolina, were found guilty of trespassing on protected computers, and for possessing stolen email addresses, in violation of the country's highly publicised "CAN-SPAM" Act of 2003. 

Jaynes and DeGroot are estimated to have sent out hundreds of millions of unwanted emails, promoting everything from pornographic websites to work-at-home schemes. According to prosecutors, the duo made over $24m from their operations.

The "CAN-SPAM" (Controlling the Assault of Non-Solicited Pornography and Marketing) Act was passed in January 2003, to curb the growing menace of digital junk mail, which accounts for up to 90% of global email traffic. The law makes it illegal to use misleading subject lines, falsify the sender's address, or fail to include a physical postal address in the email.

Jaynes, considered one of the ten "most prolific" spammers globally was convicted on three felony charges and faces up to 15 years in prison. DeGroot, who was seen as less central to the operations, was convicted on three misdemeanor charges and could face up to one year in jail.

Experts believe this case will test the potential effectiveness of the CAN-SPAM Act and could set a legal precedent. 

"The conviction of Jaynes and DeGroot is a significant victory in the fight against spam," said Virginia Attorney General Jerry Kilgore. "This case shows that laws, such as the CAN-SPAM Act, can work if effectively enforced."

The defenses for Jaynes and DeGroot claim that they were not fully aware of the full scope of the new law. They are planning to appeal.

As spam increasingly becomes a worldwide nuisance, causing billions in productivity loss, the conviction of Jaynes and DeGroot is seen as a crucial first step in holding spammers accountable for their actions. Although more high-profile spam-related trials may follow, the challenges posed by the international and anonymous nature of the internet could make enforcement a daunting task. 

Meanwhile, despite these legal measures, computer users are urged to remain vigilant and maintain online hygiene practices such as not opening unknown emails and keeping their software updated. 

The sentencing date for Jaynes and DeGroot has not been set. This landmark ruling marks a significant progression in the ongoing battle against the spam scourge that plagues global digital

Manchester United's reported proposal to offer partial refunds or rebates to season ticket holders has been met with mixed reactions from fans, amid the continued disruption of the football season due to the Covid-19 pandemic. 

The club, which has around 55,000 season ticket holders, proposed a scheme that would allow fans to get partial refunds or a rebate on their season tickets if the remaining matches continue to be played behind closed doors or are cancelled. However, some supporters have criticised the proposal, arguing that a full refund should be offered considering the exceptional circumstance.

Mahmoud Abdullah, a season ticket holder for over ten years said, "It feels like they are trying to capitalise on our loyalty. They should be offering a full refund regardless of whether the game is played behind closed doors or not. None of us could have foreseen this pandemic and we shouldn't be penalised for it."

On the other hand, some fans have commended the club for considering the financial implications for supporters during these trying times. Samantha Moore, another long-time fan said, "I think its a fair offer during the current crisis. Most clubs wouldn't even consider a refund."

The club's forum, which includes representatives from the Manchester United Supporters Trust, has also voiced its opinion on the matter. Trust spokesperson, Kim Stratford, said, "While we appreciate the club considering refunds or rebates, it's important for the final decision to be a fair assessment considering the exceptional circumstances."

Manchester United, the third richest club in the world according to Deloitte, has not yet made any official agreement regarding the proposal. It falls in line with other top-tier football clubs across Europe who are trying to find solutions for ticket holders amidst the hiatus in sporting events due to the pandemic.

Man Utd club representatives have refused to give an official comment until a decision is finalised. As it stands, the final decision will not only massively impact Manchester United's loyal fan base, but it may also set a precedent for other clubs' approaches to tackling the financial implications caused by the global coronavirus crisis. 

The club's handling of this issue will certainly act as a litmus test of their ability to reconcile the commercial interests of the club with the goodwill of their fan base in unprecedented times. Supporters will no doubt be closely watching how this plays out over the coming weeks.

Microsoft has begun an extensive probe into an alleged spyware Trojan that some security experts believe have potentially infected millions of computers across the world.

The Redmond-based giant has alerted users of a sophisticated Trojan, dubbed as 'TrojanSpy:Win32/Bancos.AZ'. The company announced that it is currently in the process of investigating the software, considered to be a severe threat to computer users.

Trojans are typically used by cybercriminals to gain illicit access to users' systems, often leading to data theft or damage. This particular Trojan appears to be categorised as spyware because of its ability to remotely monitor users' behaviour, extract sensitive information, and transmit it back to the attacker.

In a recent blog post, Microsoft's security team describes the Trojan as having the capability to monitor keystrokes and capture screenshots. Those are key tactics in stealing personal information like banking details or passwords.

The software giant advises users to keep their systems updated with the latest patches and are urged to run regular antivirus scans with up-to-date software. Moreover, the company has included detection for this Trojan in its Windows Defender antivirus software.

Although it's not yet clear how widespread the Trojan is, or how many machines have been affected, Microsoft is making significant efforts to mitigate the potential damage. The company has also reinforced its commitment to working with law enforcement agencies globally to take down the infrastructure supporting such espionage campaigns.

The existence of such spyware reinforces concerns about the cybersecurity landscape globally. It underscores the ever-present need for robust, comprehensive cybersecurity policies and practices through both individual vigilance and collective action. 

Microsoft's ongoing investigation points to the tech giant's commitment to securing its systems and protecting its users' data. They join ranks with other leading tech companies who have taken stern measures to combat the cyber threats posed by Trojan attacks.

This development also comes amidst a backdrop of increased corporate surveillance and the emergence of privacy issues as hot-button topics worldwide. The investigation into the Trojan by Microsoft is thus particularly significant given the company's wide-reaching global influence and its potential implications for cyber security standards worldwide. 

Microsoft is expected to release further information about the detected Trojan as and when their investigation progresses. Until then, customers are advised to remain vigilant, regularly update their system defenses, and report any suspicious activity to Microsoft's security team promptly.

In a major landmark of the digital age, mobile phones have now been part of our lives for two eventful decades. From the chunky devices of the late 90s to today's sleek smartphones, the evolution of the technology has utterly changed the way we communicate, work and play.

The first generation of mobile phones was launched in the 1980s, but these were mainly intended for business use. The transition to personal use began in earnest in the mid to late 90s, bringing the tech revolution to consumers' fingertips.

The way we have adopted and adapted to this technology over the past 20 years tells a remarkable story about the power of convenience and connection. Nowadays, the mobile phone serves as a personal assistant, a gaming machine, a fitness tracker, an in-pocket cinema, a research library, and much more. 

According to research, there are now around 5.20 billion unique mobile users in the world today. This figure has seen an increase of 2.4 percent compared to the previous year. 

This ubiquity, however, has not been without its challenges. The same technology that allows us to connect with anyone across the globe also raises issues of cybersecurity, data privacy, and even contributes to mental health problems arising from overuse and dependence.

It has become a common sight to see people huddled over small screens in public places, tapping away at their virtual keyboards. Families at dinner tables are often distracted by pinging notifications, and mobile phones have become a constant bedside companion, staying plugged into the digital world, even when we are struggling for a good nights sleep.

The rise of social media platforms - like Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, and Twitter - and other apps like Zoom, Teams, and Skype, have made mobile phones indispensable. Plus, the rise in e-commerce, banking, and money transfer services that we now rely on have morphed mobile phones into a tiny multipurpose tool that continues to evolve.

Yet, the potential implications on our social habits and mental health have raised concerns about how we manage our relationship with technology. The fear of missing out (FOMO) and nomophobia (fear of being without a mobile phone) are only some of recent phenomena born out of our increasing dependence.

As we stay tuned to our screens, waiting for the next call, message, or notification, it's worth reflecting on how much our lives have been shaped by mobile phones over the past 20 years. And with new advancements such as 5G, augmented reality (AR), and virtual reality

A fresh row has erupted over the advice given to former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair before the 2003 invasion of Iraq. An important memo, discovered by an independent inquiry team, suggests that Blair was warned against the attack, a stark contradiction to assertions made by the former PM, inflaming a new round of discussions around the controversial decision.

The document, intended for internal circulation within the then-government, reportedly includes advice from legal experts which outlines potential ramifications of the invasion. Lawyers within the legal office of the Foreign & Commonwealth Office, argued that the attack could be classified as an act of aggression and contravenes sections of international law.

The fact that Blair was seemingly cautioned against the Iraq invasion blows yet another hole in the already weakened credibility of the government's decisions in the run-up to the war. Critics argue that not only did the government overlook advice stating that the reasons for invasion were unfeasible, but it now appears they ignored legal advice as well. 

The former government has long claimed to have acted according to the best available advice, and with complete legitimacy. However, this recent revelation paints a different picture, adding to a string of damaging revelations that already surround the Iraq inquiry.

Members of the opposition, along with numerous legal analysts, have called for greater transparency on the decision-making processes that led up to the invasion. There have been amplified calls for an exhaustive inquiry into the reasons why such advice was allegedly sidestepped. 

Meanwhile, Hugh Bartol, a renowned legal scholar, has commented that ignoring such expert advice could be seen as a "gross dereliction of duty". Bartol said, This raises serious questions about the judgement of those at the highest level of government, as well as the mechanisms through which crucial decisions of international importance are made.

This fresh revelation is fueling those demanding accountability for the decision to invade Iraq, and adding fuel to calls for a comprehensive, open investigation into the details surrounding the choices made in the run-up to the war. Former government officials have yet to respond meaningfully to these allegations, instead reiterating their belief in the justness of the action.

As it stands, the full extent of the advice given to Blair at the time is still not public. As this matter unfolds, the public is left contemplating the actions of its leaders, the ramifications of the invasion, and the profound consequences of decisions made almost two decades ago.

The continued rise of mobile phones combined with an increase in digital communication has led to uncertainty over the future of home phones in the UK.

While statistics show that there has been a significant decline in home phone usage, they are still a fixture in many UK households. New data reveals that in 2020, 22% of UK adults no longer used or did not have a home phone. This is a considerable increase from 15% in 2017, according to figures released by the communications regulator, Ofcom.

Communication habits have evolved significantly over the last decade. Email, messaging apps, and video calls on platforms like Zoom and Skype have replaced traditional landline calls for many. Data from Ofcom shows that the total volume of outgoing call minutes from UK landlines fell by 50% from 2012 to 2020.

The ease of use of mobile phones and the convenience they represent make them the preferred choice for many. They also offer a range of functionalities that home phones cannot match, such as internet access, games, and social apps. This could be contributing to the decline.

The pandemic has accelerated this trend in many respects. With remote working becoming the norm for many, the need for a landline has further decreased. People are relying more on digital communication tools over traditional ones.

Broadband providers have noticed the change, with many offering packages that don't involve a landline. Virgin Media, one of the UK's major broadband providers, launched a broadband-only service in 2020, enabling customers to stay connected without the need for a home phone.

Despite the drastic shift, it's too soon to write the obituary for landlines. For some demographics, particularly the elderly population, home phones remain crucial. Many senior citizens find comfort and familiarity in using landlines, and for many, it remains their primary mode of communication. Text-heavy smartphones can often seem daunting and impractical for older users.

Moreover, landlines provide a reliable backup for emergencies. Mobile phone services can sometimes be unstable or affected by certain geographical factors, areas of weak or no signal, whereas a landline offers a robust and stable connection, especially in rural parts of the UK.

Only time will tell if the traditional landline can regain its ground or continue its path into obsolescence. But for now, home phones continue to ring, albeit with somewhat less frequency.

London-based Wembley plc has made an unexpected announcement revealing that the company will not be generating a profit this financial year. The revelation came as a surprise to investors and industry analysts who had projected a profitable year for the events management institution that had previously always maintained an upward trajectory.

Wembley plc, which manages the Wembley Stadium and Wembley Arena, is one of the foremost companies in event management providing locals and tourists with unforgettable entertainment experiences. Despite the companys robust portfolio that includes globally recognised celebrities and internationally acclaimed events, the company has still faced a significant downturn.

Whilst industry experts predicted a minor slump due to the ongoing pandemic affecting global tourism and events, the declaration of no profits came as a severe shock. Wembley's spokesperson stated that health restrictions had hit the company harder than anticipated which led to the cancellation of concerts, sports games and other large-scale events.

The spokesperson also highlighted that Wembley plc had to bear massive unforeseen expenses due to the modification of their operations to fit government guidelines. Wembley had to spend a significant amount on seating obstructions and additional sanitation precautions to guarantee safety, and this increased operational cost has now eaten at their profits.

Analysts believe no profit in the current financial year could potentially strain the company's cash flow and might force Wembley plc to balance its books either by laying off staff or securing liquidity through bank loans, bonds or selling assets.

The news of Wembley's financial struggle comes at a time when many businesses are grappling with losses due to the ongoing global crises caused by the pandemic. The entertainment and hospitality sectors, in particular, have been hit hardest thanks to forced cancellations and lockdowns, with many once-thriving powerhouses now teetering on the brink of solvency.

The surprising news from a stable company like Wembley plc underscores the seriousness of the current economic climate, and the potential for broader economic repercussions still looms large. With us not even halfway through the year, only time will tell if and how this cherished company, like many others, will find a way to navigate the choppy waters of these uncertain times.

Stan Lee, a titan in the realm of comic books and a legendary storyteller, left an indelible mark on the industry with his uniquely human and relatable superheroes. He was often referred to as a real-life superhero himself, shaping a world filled with characters that became cultural icons and changed the landscape of American entertainment.

Born on December 28, 1922, in New York City, Lee's career spanned seven decades, from serving as an assistant at Timely Comics - a predecessor of Marvel Comics - in the 1930s to becoming Marvel's Editor-in-Chief by the 1960s. Under Lee's stewardship, Marvel launched a slew of unforgettable characters and epic storylines that were groundbreaking in their effect on popular culture.

On the canvas of paper and with the armory of words, Lee's comic book genius sprung to life through superheroes like Spiderman, Iron Man, the X-Men, the Fantastic Four, the Incredible Hulk, Black Widow, and countless others. Unlike their god-like predecessors in the genre, these superheroes were human and flawed and, most importantly, relatable. They were individuals who, while grappling with superpowers, also dealt with everyday life problems - love, loss, anger, and disbelief.

Lee's approach to his characters was innovative for its time, taking a significant detour from the prevailing trope of infallible superheroes sporting capes and otherworldly personas. This touch of human realism that Lee injected into comic books changed the landscape of the genre, providing readers with characters that, despite their extraordinary abilities, they could identify with.

Through his characters, Lee also addressed critical social issues. He explored themes of racism, discrimination, and social alienity, particularly epitomised in characters like the X-Men, a group of mutant superheroes shunned by society for their differences. Through his larger-than-life characters and narratives, he also imbued valuable life lessons - bravery, honesty, responsibility, and the importance of standing up for the oppressed.

Lee's influence went beyond paper and ink and transcended mediums, contributing significantly to some of the highest-grossing films and series made by Hollywood in recent decades. Through collaborations with studios and filmmakers, Lee's characters and stories gained global recognition, forever transforming the cinematic landscape.

He also pioneered the "Marvel Method" of writing comics - a collaborative approach where Lee would detail the storyline to an illustrator, the illustrator would then craft the comic, and finally, Lee would add dialogues. This approach not only made the process more efficient but also granted more creative

In response to increasing concerns over public health, the police are now urging for the authority to close pubs and bars that are found to be in violation of Covid-19 guidelines, according to the latest developments. 

Police forces across the UK have reported growing frustrations as they attempt to enforce new Covid-19 restrictions. Under the proposed measures, officers would have the power to immediately shut down any pubs, bars, or other venues that are failing to comply with the UK Government's social distancing rules or other public health measures.

This proposal comes after a significant rise in Covid-19 cases in the UK, with many outbreaks linked to the hospitality sector. Representatives from different police forces have noted a growing number of establishments failing to follow Covid-19 guidelines, thus putting customers and local communities at higher risk.

The National Police Chiefs' Council (NPCC) said the proposed powers would better equip the police to ensure public safety. A spokesperson for the NPCC stated: "We need stronger powers to act swiftly in situations where pubs flout the rules and become unsafe."

The NPCC statement also revealed that currently, any Coronavirus law violations made by pubs and bars can only result in fines. However, the new set of powers would provide police with discretion to close down problematic establishments immediately, protecting public health more effectively.

There has been a mixed response to the proposal, with some stakeholders in the hospitality sector wary that it could further push already struggling businesses to the brink.

The British Beer and Pub Association said it was "vital" that businesses were given "clear, precise instructions" on the regulations, enabling them to keep their doors open while also maintaining safety measures. 

However, proponents argue that the new powers would target only a small number of venues and would not be used indiscriminately. The focus, they say, would be on penalising pubs and bars that repeatedly and flagrantly disregard Covid-19 laws, helping to safeguard the wider public from increased risk of infection.

This proposal is currently under review by the UK government, and a decision is expected in the coming days. The police continue to advise the public to avoid crowded places wherever possible and to follow safe social distancing practices.

Global automotive giant Daimler AG is weathering a significant downturn in its Mercedes-Benz sector. Owing to a combination of factors, one of the biggest names associated with luxury cars globally is faced with plummeting sales and a soaring financial deficit.

Mercedes-Benz, the crown jewel of Germany's Daimler AG, witnessed a sharp decline in its third-quarter sales as a result of global chip shortages, supply chain disruption, and economic impacts brought about by the pandemic.

According to reports, the shortage of semiconductors, an essential component for the manufacturing of modern cars, has crippled carmakers worldwide. Mercedes-Benz, renowned for its advanced technological integration, has been hit especially hard. 

The auto-giant's projected earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) have reportedly dropped a staggering 60% compared to last year's third quarter. This fall from a previously soaring 3.07 Billion ($3.58bn) to a mere 1.2 Billion ($1.39bn) year on-year, setting alarm bells ringing at the Stuttgart-based company.

The alarming slump cannot solely be attributed to the global chip shortage. Disruptions in global trade and logistics, triggered by the pandemic, are causing supply chain blockages for automakers, undermining their ability to deliver and maintain their market position.

These problems are further amplified by an economic slowdown in key markets. China, a significant market for Mercedes-Benz, has seen slowed growth due to government regulations on its property sector, impacting its luxury goods market's development. Profitability in the North American market has also come under strain due to dealership closures prompted by the pandemic.

In an attempt to tide over these challenging times, Daimler recently announced plans to invest 40bn ($47bn) to electrify all Mercedes-Benz passenger car models by 2030. However, the immediate financial adverse effect of this slump is undeniable, with shares in Daimler falling approximately 2% on the Frankfurt exchange, consequently wiping out over 1 billion ($1.2bn) in market value.

With the economic fallout of the pandemic continuing and no immediate end in sight to the global chip shortage, Daimler AG's road to recovery may indeed be an uphill one. The automotive behemoth will need to pull out all the stops to navigate through what's shaping up to be one of the industry's most challenging periods.

In a surprising political move, a Conservative MP has defected to the Labour Party which is said to create a stir in both camps. 

The MP, whose name is currently under wraps, citing irreconcilable policy differences with the current government and its leadership as the reason for his shifting alliance. The MP represents a Midlands seat, which has traditionally swung between the two main parties. 

His unexpected decision comes at a time of growing tension within the Conservative party, with disagreements over various policy matters. This includes the handling of the ongoing pandemic, the recent tax rise, and the country's approach to climate change.

The Labour leader has welcomed what he calls this 'bold and principled' decision. "I think it shows that we in the Labour Party are offering a serious alternative to the government, the Labour leader said.

However, his move has not been without controversy. The local Conservative party branded the defection a betrayal and called for a by-election. The public deserves the opportunity to pass judgment on this dishonourable act, they said in a statement.

Despite a potential backlash, the MP said, he believed that he was following the right path. He stated his goals to "truly represent constituents' interests", and said, I can no longer do this within the confines of the Conservative party."

In his own statement, Prime Minister responded to the MP's defection by saying that his government was "completely focused" on dealing with the country's key issues. While not mentioning the MP specifically, he added that those who disagreed were "free to choose their path". 

Details of any role the MP might play in the Labour Party, or whether he will seek re-election under their banner, have not been disclosed. Highlighting the possibility of further defections, political commentator, Alex Holmes, commented: When one MP defects, others could well follow. This could potentially cause trouble for the prime minister.

This move could also strengthens Labour's position in the Midlands - a region where both parties are vying for key seats ahead of the next general election. As the unexpected political saga unfolds, the nation will keenly watch further developments.

Several high-profile celebrities have hunkered down in the heart of the wild jungle, as part of an upcoming reality television series, which aims to go beyond the glitz and glam of stardom to test the survival skills of these popular personalities.

The series, which remains untitled, showcases twelve celebrities striving to thrive in the rugged terrains of the Amazon Rainforest over a period of six weeks. They will face real, hands-on survival challenges, which will include building their own shelters, finding food, and staying safe in the unfamiliar environment.

The star-studded lineup includes award-winning actors, acclaimed musicians and champion athletes, all set to swap their luxurious lifestyles for a taste of raw adventure. A full list of participants is yet to be confirmed, but sources suggest we could see familiar faces like action superstar Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, British adventurer Bear Grylls, or pop-music icon Rihanna.

"It's not an easy task at all, but it's definitely going to be an unforgettable, life-changing experience for those who are taking part," said the show's executive producer, John Stevenson.

This move may be seen as a reaction to the continued success of celebrity survival shows like I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! and Bear Grylls' Celebrity Island, which have gained massive popularity in recent years due to their unique blend of celebrity culture and survival competitions.

The series will offer a unique behind-the-scenes look at the celebrities' experience as they navigate their way through the dense jungle. There will be limited intervention from the production team, enabling the stars to genuinely experience the difficulties of jungle survival.

The show promises to deliver some unforgettable moments, as friendships are forged in the face of adversity, primordial instincts awaken, and the endurance of the celebs is pushed to its limits. This compelling juxtaposition of the celebrities' usual plush lifestyle with one of dressing in basic outdoor gear, sleeping under the stars, and attempting to start fire, is bound to draw in viewers worldwide.

The series is set to air in the summer of 2023. So, it's time to kick back and watch our beloved stars wrestle with not only jungle life but also their innermost fears and insecurities.

Football commentator and former professional player Graeme Souness has expressed interest in recruiting former England striker Michael Owen in the summer transfer window. Owen, a free agent since his departure from Stoke City in 2013, is yet to comment on the potential move.

This potential hiring would mark an intriguing chapter in Owen's illustrious career, which includes stints with Liverpool, Real Madrid, Newcastle United and Manchester United. Meanwhile, Souness, the former Liverpool and Rangers manager, now a respected pundit on Sky Sports, has consistently praised Owen's abilities on-air.

Speaking on Sky Sports, Souness stated, "There aren't many players like Michael out there anymore. His eye for a goal and his ability to stay fit for a substantial part of a season, despite his age, is what makes him a valuable player."

Experts are divided on how Owen, now 41, would fit into the competitive world of top-tier football after a long hiatus. However, Souness is confident in his abilities. "At this stage of his life, he's not the youngster who arrived at Liverpool with bags of potential," Souness acknowledged, "But he's still got the quality and experience we need."

The former Liverpool manager's admiration for Owen is well-documented. During their shared time at Liverpool, Souness was full of praise for the striker, whom he described as "one of the best finishers I've ever seen". Their enduring professional respect could be the driving force behind this potential move.

Details of the transfer, such as the duration of Owen's contract and the potential role he would play in Souness' side, remain unclear. As the transfer window approaches, fans will eagerly await confirmation of Owen's potential return to football.

Owen's possible recruitment by Souness could add a stunning twist to this summer's transfer window drama, reaffirming Souness' unorthodox and determined approach to team building.

Former world number one, Jennifer Capriati, has withdrawn from the Australian Open tennis tournament due to a persistent shoulder injury. The 36-year-old American, who won the event in 2001 and 2002, is yet to recover from a right-shoulder surgery she underwent last year.

The Women's Tennis Association confirmed the news, stating that, "Jennifer is still in the recovery process and has not been able to achieve the ideal fitness level to compete in such a demanding tournament." Despite showing signs of progress, her team believes that rushing her back could potentially exacerbate her injury.

Capriati's withdrawal is a blow to the tournament due to her immense popularity down under. Her comeback victory in 2002, where she came back from a set down to clinch the women's singles title, is still fondly remembered by many Australian Open fans.

Making her professional debut at the tender age of 13, Capriati quickly rose to international fame by winning the Olympic Gold for singles in Barcelona in 1992. However, her career was interrupted by personal troubles. After a six month hiatus, she made her on-court comeback in 1996 and enjoyed a steady ascending career trajectory that culminated in a world number one ranking in 2001.

Her decision to pull out from the Open is in line with her history of prioritisng her health above all else. Even at the height of her career, Capriati showed the maturity to step away from the game when her physical and emotional health demanded it.

The American, who has a total of 14 singles titles to her credit, has not commented on whether this latest setback could result in her retirement from professional tennis. She had been planning to use the Australian Open as a platform to assess the state of her game ahead of a full season on the WTA Tour.

However, it appears that tennis fans will have to wait a bit longer to witness the return of one of the sport's most inspirational figures. The Australian Open, which kicks off in Melbourne on January 15th, has yet to announce who will replace Capriati in the draw.

Internet users worldwide are being urged to exercise caution when conducting online transactions, following an increase in the recorded number of internet scams. Experts, businesses and regulators are calling for concerted efforts to fight back against this growing menace.

This plea follows a report by the Internet Fraud Watchdog (IFW), which highlighted a 30 per cent rise in global cyber scams in 2021. The body is requesting governments and tech companies to intensify preventative measures, educate the public and establish tougher penalties for perpetrators.

Among the most widespread scams observed are phishing, identity theft, advanced fee fraud and bogus online auctions. Often, these scams prey upon users' lack of understanding and awareness involving the security pitfalls of digital transactions. 

"Internet scams are evolving at a faster pace than our efforts to combat them," warns Ruth Everhart, Senior Analyst at the IFW. "Cybercriminals are using increasingly sophisticated techniques to exploit unsuspecting victims, especially in the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic, where people have become more reliant on digital platforms."

Indeed, the global shift towards remote working, online shopping and digital banking as a result of COVID-19 has seen an increased reliance on the internet - a reality not lost on cybercriminals. Many have taken advantage of these new behavioural habits and increased their fraudulent activities.

Several prominent e-commerce websites, digital platforms and banks have joined the call for action, pledging to bolster their security systems while also emphasising user responsibility in avoiding scams.

James Kilby, Head of Cybersecurity at Thanos Bank, says, "Even as we ramp up our security systems, users play a significant role in their own security. They need to be vigilant about suspicious emails and links, regularly update their passwords, and most importantly, stay informed about the different scamming techniques."

Campaigners are also urging users to report scams to the authorities immediately. This helps the concerned bodies to act promptly, curbing the spread of such fraudulent activities.

Governments internationally are responding to these calls for action, launching digital literacy campaigns and tightening up anti-fraud regulations. However, the rapidly evolving nature of cybercrime represents significant challenges, presenting a need for constant updating of security systems and public awareness campaigns.

With online transactions set to grow even further, the battle against internet scams will continue to be a focal point. The synergy of efforts from the users, technology companies, businesses and governments will be crucial to keeping the digital world safe. 

No one measure will be enough to eradicate this issue entirely. However, by working collaboratively, the hope is that the frequency

Bookmakers have placed their bets on the critically acclaimed film "Aviator" as the favourite for this year's Oscar awards. Predicting the direction the Academy Awards will lean towards for Best Picture, leading bookmakers favor this epic biographical drama, almost guaranteeing its Oscar success. 

Powerful performances, deft direction, and an engrossing narrative have charmed not just film critics, but bookies as well who are convinced of "Aviator's" triumph at the 87th Academy Awards. Already the recipient of multiple awards and accolades, the film's unrelenting momentum on the prize circuit has fortified its position as the frontrunner.

UK's largest betting company, Ladbrokes, has reportedly placed odds of 2-1 in favor of "Aviator", while Irish bookmaker Paddy Power offers slightly more conservative odds at 7-2. William Hill, another prominent British bookmaker, has also expressed similar confidence in the film's success by offering odds of 3-1.

Notably, while odds can fluctuate and pre-ceremony betting doesn't ensure victory, the bookmakers' predictions have traditionally been spot-on when it comes to foreseeing Oscar winners.

The film, helmed by celebrated director Martin Scorsese, offers a compelling depiction of aviation pioneer Howard Hughes' life during the 19281947 period. With commanding performances by its star-studded cast, including Leonardo DiCaprio in the lead role, the "Aviator" has been flying high ever since its release.

However, competition is still fierce with other notable films like Sideways, "Million Dollar Baby", and "Finding Neverland" vying for the same prestigious award. While "Aviator" leads odds, surprises can never be wholly ruled out in the quest for the golden statue.

The Academy Awards, Hollywood's most awaited annual spectacle celebrating cinematic excellence, will reveal its winners in a glamorous ceremony later this year. Whether the industry experts and bookmakers have predicted right will only be answered on the much-anticipated Oscars night.

We'll all be watching to see whether the "Aviator" soars high above its competitors or if an underdog comes out on top.

The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) has expressed its disagreement with a recent decision taken by Greece's athletics body. The governing body of the athletics has confirmed that it will challenge the controversial ruling.

Following many allegations of corruption and a series of high-profile doping scandals, Greece's athletics body had made the controversial decision to suspend various events and competitions until further reformations take place.

The IAAF, however, is firmly opposed to this blanket operation ban, stating that these steps might have profound consequences on the careers of 'clean' athletes who have no involvement in any illicit activity.

The President of the IAAF, Sebastian Coe, emphasized in a recent statement, "We absolutely support the drive towards a cleaner, more transparent sport. However, halting all athletics events is not the solution. This penalizes innocent athletes who have dedicated their lives to the sport."

Coe, while openly critical of the missteps in the Greek athletics body, recommended a more balanced approach. He suggested the provision of more substantial resources to fund stringent doping tests and enhance structures aimed at tackling corruption, instead of closing all competitions.

"There are many athletes in Greece who maintain the principles of fair play and the spirit of the sport. They should not lose the opportunity to display their talent and hard work because of the misdeeds by a few," he added.

The IAAF will be petitioning the Court of Arbitration for Sport to contest the Greek decision. The international body believes that this drastic action risks damaging the reputation of athletics globally, as well as potentially endangering the career of law-abiding athletes.

Set against a backdrop of repeated instances of corruption and doping, Greece's extreme step has sent ripples throughout the athletics world. Meanwhile, the IAAF's opposition underlines its determination to protect the rights of every athlete to compete.

The forthcoming decision by the Court of Arbitration for Sport will be consequential, not just for Greek athletics but also for the international athletics community. It will set a precedent on how to handle corruption and doping scandals, a growing concern in sports worldwide.

In an unexpected turn of events, struggling Australian sprinter Jack Gardener has stormed to a triumphant victory, casting pre-race predictions to the wind. Despite being considered off-form due to his recent struggles with injury, Gardener arguably delivered his best performance to date.

Gardener, fondly known as 'The Australian Bolt', wasn't amongst the favourites to win the 200m race at the Athletics World Championships. Having spent much of the season nursing a persistent hamstring injury, his form on the track had been far from spectacular.

However, the Australian speedster showed everyone just why he was once considered one of the brightest talents in athletics. He blasted off the blocks, claiming a lead he would never relinquish and crossing the finish line under 20 seconds, a feat only a handful of athletes can boast.

"I knew I had it in me," Gardener said post-race, his eyes still gleaming with the thrill of his victory. "I've been battling injury, but never lost faith in my ability. This victory goes to my coaches, my team, and all who believed in me."

Earlier in the year, Jack's form had been a cause for concern. Having ruled the 200m circuit domestically, this season has been one of picking up the pieces following a disappointing last-place finish at the National Trials.

"There were serious discussions about whether he could continue at this level," said Alan Briggs, Gardener's coach. "But Jack's a fighter, he pulled himself together and trained harder than ever. Today's victory is a testament to his resilience."

Doubters had written Gardener off before the race, citing his injury problems and lack in confidence as significant obstacles to his performance. But in a striking display of determination, the Australian star shrugged off all setbacks to produce a stunning run, breathing new life into his faltering career.

In a nail-biting finish, Gardener pipped American sensation Demetrius Hilson, the reigning World Champion, by 0.01 seconds. In doing so, Gardener not only gave his best performance to date, but he also set a new Australian record, firmly silencing his critics.

As he stood atop the podium, draped in the Australian flag, one could sense a shift in the air. Gardener has sent out a message loud and clear that he's far from done, and perhaps just getting started. This victory symbolises a potential comeback for the "Off-colour" runner and could serve as a turning point in his illustrious career.

British tennis superstar Andy Murray is set to create a historic moment in the world of tennis as he has been announced to play in the 2021 Davis Cup. This prestigious event will mark Murray's twelfth participation, making him the British player with the most appearances in the tournament's history.

Murray, ranked third in the world, has been an iconic figure in British tennis for many years, claiming three Grand Slam titles, two Olympic gold medals, and initiating a crucial role in the GB team's 2015 Davis Cup victory. 

The British player has been an essential element of the Davis Cup team since his debut in 2005. He has guided the country to numerous victories and incredibly climactic matches that fans worldwide will remember for years to come.

British Tennis Captain, Leon Smith, underlined what this means saying, "Andy's record speaks for itself, and it's a proud moment for him and British tennis. His dedication and contribution to the team is commendable. We're incredibly lucky to have a player of his calibre representing us."

Murray, despite dealing with physical setbacks, including hip surgery in 2019, has shown notable determination to get back to his peak. His commitment to the sport and his determination to continually improve is what sets him apart, maintaining his place amongst the top-ranked players in the world.

"It's an honour to be representing Great Britain again. The Davis Cup has always held a special place in my heart, and I'm excited to be making history with my twelfth appearance," Murray stated during an interview.

With Murray at the reins, there is immense anticipation moving forward for Great Britain at the Davis Cup this year. The tournament will kick off in Madrid on November 25, and supporters worldwide cannot wait to see Murray take the court and potentially guide his nation to another remarkable victory.

The potential implications of this tournament are massive, not just for Murray's individual career, but also for the future of British tennis. Indeed, this historic participation could be the catalyst for more significant milestones in the sport.

Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced that petrol duties will be held static, in a move cheered by motorists and retail associations. The announcement comes amid rising fuel costs and inflation worries.

Mr. Brown reassured millions of drivers across the country that fuel duties would be frozen for the remainder of the current fiscal year. This decision comes in the wake of significantly escalating petrol prices, which have placed considerable economic pressure on drivers, businesses and consumers alike.

The Chancellor explained the freeze as part of a larger effort to cushion the UK economy against the impacts of international oil price fluctuations. The UK's fuel duty, one of the highest in the world, has been a controversial topic for years. However, according to Mr. Brown, this freeze will ensure that drivers are not unduly burdened during these volatile economic times.

"The government is committed to helping British motorists - particularly during these times of economic uncertainty," said Mr. Brown. The freeze in fuel duty will help family budgets and businesses across the Country.

Petrol retailers and driver associations have welcomed the announcement saying it brought much-needed relief. The Freight Transport Association described it as a "fragile lifeline" for struggling hauliers who are grappling with the impact of soaring fuel costs on their operations.

Meanwhile, environmental groups have expressed concern that the freeze on fuel duty could discourage the necessary shift towards more environmentally friendly modes of transport.

This announcement came as a surprise to some, as Mr. Brown, in his March budget, had originally planned to increase petrol taxes by 2p per litre beginning from September. However, given record fuel prices and the ongoing cost of living concerns, the chancellor decided to hold off on implementing this potential rise.

The chancellor concluded his announcement by reiterating the government's commitment to a fair and balanced approach to economic policy - protecting the interests of consumers, businesses, and the environment.

Protesters are gearing up to stage a significant demonstration at one of the UK's major airports. The demonstration, planned for the coming weeks, is anticipated to disrupt the airport's regular operations, aiming to draw attention to the protesters' cause.

The protest is being co-ordinated by numerous environmental groups who are collectively aiming to challenge the airport's expansion plans. They have consistently expressed concerns that increased air traffic will significantly contribute to climate change due to higher greenhouse gas emissions.

The airport, which has asked not to be named for security reasons, has recently announced plans to build a new runway to cater to the increasing demand. The expansion plan has provoked a fierce response from environmental activists who cite the harmful effects of air travel on the environment and the need for alternative transport modes.

Green Earth United, one of the main environmental organisations leading the protest, says it's not a decision they have taken lightly. "We comprehend the inconvenience our protest might cause to travelers, but we firmly believe that the long-term effects of airport expansion pose a greater threat," said a spokesperson for the group.

The protesters have promised that their demonstration will be peaceful and are preparing to face arrests if necessary. They plan on employing non-violent civil disobedience tactics, such as blocking roads leading to the airport and staging sit-ins at the terminals.

Airport authorities have expressed their concern regarding the potential disruption to their services and the impact it may have on passengers. They reassured the public that they are working closely with the police to ensure the safety and minimal disruption for passengers.

A representative from the airport said, "While we respect the right to peaceful protest and agree on the urgency of addressing climate change, we cannot allow any actions that might put the safe and smooth operation of the airport at risk."

The proposed protest is part of a series of actions by climate activists across the country demanding the government take more drastic measures to combat climate change. As the day of the protest draws closer, it remains to be seen how this confrontation between environmental protestors and airport authorities will unfold.

Gold prices have seen a substantial decline amid worries that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) might sell part of its gold reserves, a move that could potentially flood the market and lower the value of the yellow metal.

Last trading session saw the price of spot gold falling by 0.6% to $1,820 per ounce, reversing gains made earlier in the week. US gold futures also dropped 0.7% at $1,822.40.

The drop in prices comes after speculation that the IMF might resort to sell its gold amid the COVID-19 pandemic to support struggling economies. The IMF holds a total of 2,814 metric tonnes of gold at designated depositories, making it one of the largest institutional holders of gold in the world.

"The markets are reacting to speculations about a potential IMF gold sale, leading to a sell-off", said Xiao Fu, Head of Commodity Market Strategy at Bank of China International. "However, an actual sale is complicated and could take time due to the requirement of approval by the IMF board."

The bullion market was further weighed down by an advancing dollar, which makes gold more expensive for holders of other currencies. The dollar index, measuring the greenback against a basket of six major currencies, rose 0.2% on Friday.

Despite these pressures, analysts are optimistic for gold's long-term outlook. "Gold remains a long-term buy. Central banks are still accommodative, and real interest rates remain negative. Once these IMF sale rumours are digested, gold prices should lift again," said Michael Langford, executive director at corporate advisory and consultancy firm AirGuide.

Yet, experts also warn that short-term fluctuations in gold prices are common due to speculation and macroeconomic uncertainties. Investors are therefore urged to exercise prudence and maintain a diversified portfolio.

The IMF's touted sale is not without precedent. In 2009-2010, it sold over 400 metric tonnes of gold, citing a similar reason of supporting member countries. The decision had significant implications for the global bullion market, contributing to a moderate fall in prices. However, market scale, liquidity and demand dynamics have changed since and it remains to be seen what impact a similar move would yield now.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has confirmed that it has approved additional financial assistance for Turkey, a move seen as a crucial attempt to support the country's struggling economy. 

The disbursement, the amount of which has not yet been disclosed, will be primarily allocated towards infrastructure development, addressing economic vulnerabilities, and promoting sustainable growth. However, critics suggest it could also result in austerity measures. 

In spite of a rapidly deteriorating economy exacerbated by ongoing geopolitical tensions, Turkey has not received IMF aid since 2008. The new agreement therefore marks a significant shift in policy both for the country and the international lender.

Acting IMF Managing Director, Tao Zhang, highlighted in the announcement that the decision aims to assist Turkey in facing its economic challenges. "It is more important than ever to strengthen Turkey's economy. This financial assistance will not only boost the country's economic stability, but also help to address inflation and unemployment problems," said Zhang.

The deal comes after lengthy discussions between the Turkish government and the international lender, demonstrating the increasing concern over the state of the Turkish economy, which has staggered under high inflation, struggling market confidence, and a plummeting lira over the past few years.

Despite the positive responses from international observers, the IMF's decision is not without criticisms. Some fear that the loan could lead to harsh austerity measures, as repayment conditions might impose severe fiscal curbs on the Turkish government.

While detailing the fundings focus areas, the IMF also stressed the necessity of comprehensive structural reforms, including enhancing transparency, fighting corruption, and improving business practices.

Turkey's Finance Minister Lutfi Elvan stated that the country was "committed to the implementation of these economic reforms."

"The Turkish government appreciates the IMFs financial support. We assure that these resources will be efficiently managed to achieve their intended objectives," said Elvan.

With the global economy facing pandemic-induced uncertainties, Turkey hopes the new funding will contribute to stabilising the state economy and its eventual recovery.

Ringtones sellers are to face stringent new regulations in an effort to clamp down on unscrupulous practices and protect consumers, under new rules announced by the UK telecoms regulator. The move follows a significant rise in complaints from mobile phone users about excessive costs and hidden charges.

The Ofcom regulator has said that the new rules will strongly regulate the ringtone industry, which had previously operated with relative freedom. This follows an alarming increase in the number of complaints arising from misleading advertisements, unclear subscription terms and inflated costs. 

In many cases, users reported being lured into expensive monthly subscriptions for ringtones without their explicit agreement or understanding of the terms. Several phone users also claimed to have been billed for ringtones and other mobile services that were never used or delivered.

To tackle this, Ofcom is set to introduce a number of stringent rules aimed at making sure consumers are not hoodwinked by unscrupulous companies or complex terms and conditions. The regulators new guidelines stipulate that pricing information for any ringtone service must be clearly provided to the user at the point of purchase. In addition, firms will need to take steps to ensure that customers are fully aware they have entered into a recurring payment situation.

Under the new rules, advertising and marketing communications from these companies must also be honest and transparent. They should not mislead the consumers or omit important information about the cost of the service or the duration of the contract. 

A new rule that may give further relief to the customers is the 'cooling-off' period. Companies will now be required to offer a minimum 14-day 'cooling-off' period during which customers can cancel their purchase without being charged.
